text: From notes. Enjoyed at Corbets house during a tasting on October 24. 22 oz bottle. The pour is a lighter coppery gold color with a thicker white head that slowly recedes. The aroma is tropical fruits, a little piney bitterness, and a strong biscuit malt. This isnt my jam. There is a dank citrus here, but the maltiness of this isnt for me. The flavor is a little better. The malt fades a touch, and the citrus really comes through. I like that much of it. The tropical fruits are present, and there is a pretty good bitterness on the back end that seems like it could be associated to the malts. The mouth feel is a little thick and heavy with a softer carbonation and a lingeringly sweet malty candy on the finish. Not my jam.

Holy crap this beer dropped off quickly. From talking to the person who traded for it, its one month old. Aromas are slightly tropical with a big west coast grapefruit vibe. Kind of overly bitter and slightly old hops, slight caramel. Big letdown.

Yowza. Aroma is much like Sip, sweet, tropical fruit, pine, and malt. Appearance is amber copper, light tan head. Taste is tropical fruit, lots of it, pine, slight dankness, a candy sweetness, and caramel malt, super weird and complex. Mouthfeel is medium body, light crisp carbonation, juicy candy aftertaste. Overall, Im pretty disappointed by this beer, for the hype it receives.

Bottle from Jeremy -- cheers! I had been looking forward to this one for a while, and I was amazed at how underwhelming it was when I tried it. If the normal Sip of Sunshine is complex layers of hops on a bitter and sweet base, this was just an overly sweet, supremely yeasty mess. It wasnt particularly hoppy and it tasted like some of the less successful homebrew projects Ive tasted over the years. Hopefully this was an off batch or something.

22oz bottle thanks to Steve. pours out a light hazy golden topped with a white head. Nose is tropical fruit some butter popcorn and a sweet malt. Taste is more of the tropical fruit hops a nice light bitterness and a great sweet touch.

Bottle. One of the biggest letdown beers Ive ever had. Over-hyped and not nearly worth what I had to give up to acquire this in a trade. Pours gold/orange, mostly clear, small sudsy white head. Aroma was decent and hoppy, slight pine and citrus notes. Flavor was a mess. Tasted like rotting vegetables, butter, and really earthy. I asked my friend what he tasted and he replied with one word "anger". I got a good laugh there. Medium body, sticky texture, bubbly carbonation, really bitter finish. This was my number one want beer and Ive been trying to track it down for quite some time. I finally do and its not even close to good. Either that, or I hyped it up too much or got a bad and skunked bottle. Neither of us got any tropical fruit or citrus in the flavor at all.

Bottle @ home on my sons first birthday March 14th 2016. Lightly hazy orange golden color, medium to full sized white head that lasts for a decent while. Superb hoppy aroma with tropical fruits and a slight floral note. Fantastic aroma, although it has more of an IPA character to me than an Imperial IPA, I would have loved a little pine and resin in there. Nontheless abdolutely lovely. Tastes light to moderately malty, again loads of hops dominating the initial flavor, fortunately some resin amidst the tropical fruit hops. Nice mix of fruity hop bitter and malt bitterness in the finish. Medium body and carbonation. Absolutely delicious!
On tap at Biercab. Golden colour with white head. Fruity aroma. Sweet, tropical fruits and citric taste. Medium body.

On Tap. @V Barcelona Beer Festival.Del 04 al 06/03/2016 
Color amarillo, aroma frutal intenso, final amargo. muy buena.
De tirador al BBF 2016. Espectacular doble IPA, fruitada, fresca, equilibrada i amb una alta bebilitat tot i les seus 8 graus. Boníssima!!!

Bomber, picked up at Craft Beer Cellar, Waterbury, and shared, at home, with the missus. Hazy, dark, orangey gold. Bubbly, messy, sticky, white head. A bit leggy. Looks great. Nose is orange marmalade on buttered toast, apparently. I cant disagree. Theres also tinned peach and pear, for me. Ripe strawberry. Melon. Smells fantastic. Taste is chewy sweet. Robust, fruity, resinous bitter. Feels rich, silky, oily, and hop oil juicy. Stupidly easy drinking. Finishes long, juicy, resinous bitter, with a lasting sweetness on the lips. Its a bit of a big hitter, this. A stunner.

Bottle (purchased two weeks ago tomorrow and kept cold since purchasing the warm bottle at Hunger Mountain). Pours a hazy orange with an ample, fluffy white head. Lots of messy lacing coats the glass, as I am three-fourths of the way through. Aromas of citrus and tropical fruit, some dank notes; bubble gum after it has warmed a bit and the head has dissipated. Moderately sweet up front balanced by a moderate bitterness that takes over mid-palate and builds. Love the balance. Would like it to taste juicier, though. Medium to medium+ bodied; soft carbonation; moderately bitter finish. Ive had better (and fresher) bottles of this beer and remember being blown away. This is excellent, but not quite what I remember from that first bottle at my campsite hours after purchasing it at the Waitsfield Farmers Market years ago...

Pours a bright golden with a medium white head that leaves nice lacing. Nose is of dank and resinous hops and tropical fruits. Light alcohol. Taste is lightly sweet but mostly fruity with a firm bitterness. Alcohol shows a little, but hey, its a double IPA. Mangoes. Body is medium, carbonation moderate and mouthfeel juicy. Really nice and quite similar to Heady, a bit more tropical juice and a bit less alcohol and it would be amongst my best Im sure!

Bomber bought at Winooski Beverage Warehouse.
This was poured into a Lawsons tulip.
The appearance was a hazy burnt orange almost brown color with a one finger white to off white foamy head that concaved gracefully to leave some bubbles inside of a thin white cap.
The smell starts off with a sweet onion up front and then some light tropical fruits and a delicate sweet and bitter sprucy piney stickiness.
The taste was mainly bitter backed up by a light sweet tropical fruit revolving around the pine. Bitter sticky piney-ness leading into the aftertaste and finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium in body with a good sipping quality and a danky sweet stickiness clinging to my tongue. Some slight hop oils lay down to want to allow a certain slick feel, but still indicates a well balanced oily to slick and clinginess on my tongue.
Overall, what a wonderful DIPA that I know I would have again.

Draft. An unclear golden beer with a lazing white head. The aroma has of hops, malt, exotic fruit, and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of hops, exotic fruits, alcohol, malt and straw, leading to a bitter finish

Bottle thanks to Rob. Pours a cloudy orange with medium frothy off white head that lasts leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is strong floral, tropical fruit, and dank. Thick mouth, grapefruit, pine, juicy, nice resin finish, very impressive.
floral, citrus, herbs, tropical fruits, golden, clear, white foam, rocky head, light sweetness, very bitter, thin feel, oily feel, flat, soft carbonation, long finish, bitter,

simply one of the best balanced double IPA is on the market. appearances golden exactly like the color of sunshine. aroma is full of tropical fruit notes and hops suggest what should be a very bitter beer turns out to be exceptionally well balanced. theres something about the water used by Hill farmstead Lawsons and the alchemist that makes all three of these breweries the finest in the United States. I make a trip up to Waterbury every winter and these three are by far and away the best brewers.
Blonde doré. Voilé. Entré légèrement sucré. Malté. Belle amertume. Très fruité. Agrume. Orange. Résineuse. Un peu végétale et âcre. Finale sèche et terreuse. Très bien.
Des malts à demi-sucrés qui supportent des exubérances fruitées et herbacées. Vraiment léquilibre comme signature pour Lawsons.
Abounding tropical fruit, citrus and pine, with just enough of a semi-sweet malty backbone to balance. Went down incredibly easy and had no real faults to speak of."

On mavait dit que cétait bon. On ne ma pas menti. Les murmures autour de la table voulaient comparer la fiole avec une canette de Heady Topper. Plusieurs disaient que la Lawsons Finest était meilleure. De mon côté, je navais pas envie de comparer. Je voulais juste la boire. La déguster. Et cest exactement ce que jai fait. On ne mavait pas menti... mais moi jai menti lorsquon ma demandé si jen avais déjà eu alors quil ne restait quune portion dans la bouteille. Jai eu la dernière portion et jai quitté pour la salle de bain sans remords.
650ml bottle. Golden pour, tropical fruit notes, fairly dry, some citrus, very pleasant and lighter dipa abv considered.
This is a perfect beer for me. Crisp and clean with huge hoppy aroma but not too bitter. Very balanced and drinkable

Bottle. Hazy golden pour with white head. Highly aromatic DIPA dominated by tropical fruits notes and resin. Taste is deliciously fruity and bitter with light biscuity malts. Oily mouthfeel and medium-lively carbonation. It is not a personal favourite but indeed a stellar example of the style.
Bottle. Hazy gold with a fluffy white head. Aroma and taste are awesome with tons of floral notes, orange and lemons. Crisp mouthfeel and short finish. Incredibly delicious.

Au nez, les bonbons aux pêches et les fruits tropicaux plein nez! En bouche, un goût agréable de fruits, sucre, résine et de torchon a vaisselle! La finale est amère, résineuse et sèche. La dégustation est un bonheur. Une des meilleures que j'ai bu!

Thanks to my cousin for pouring this beauty! A rich & complex IPA with lots of subtle flavor elements - fruity sweetness, pleasant bitter nip, orange, cranberry. Excellent.
Bottle w/ Coozie. Aroma though bottle nose is intense tropical fruity with a touch of pine. Taste is very fruity bitter with a full body and balanced but bitter finish. Very nice.

22oz bottle. Hazy golden orange with a frothy white head. Flavors are tropical fruits, pineapple, citrus, pine resin, biscuit and caramel with floral notes. Medium to full body, moderate carbonation, oily texture.

Pale yellow, cloudy. Very floral, some slight citrus. Some bitterness, slightly sweet. Medium body. Not a ton of carbonation. Very well balanced.

Crushed with Jakebra
Pours a hazy yellow with a medium but well retained head. 

The aroma is grassy & fruity, hop forward all around... dank at moments but basically very pungent, bright & inviting. 

The flavor is well rounded, the first thing that strikes me is how well integrated the bitterness is here, its on the lower end for the style but its just right on as far as giving the beer just the right bitter kick to be satisfying while letting the hop flavors do most of the talking. Its fruity and grassy with a good bright character throughout. There is a touch of booziness, but it drinks far more like a 6% abv beer. Everything is nicely balanced hop flavor wise while this one keeps it real low on malt character. 


This is a great example of how good the Double IPA style can be when its stripped off all the silly bravado that seems to come with the style so frequently.

Cloudy yellow with persistent foam. Aromas of lemony and resinous hop. Flavors of sweet lemon, resinous, slight bitterness of hops.

Couleur jaune citron trouble, un peu de mousse persistante. Nez de houblon citronné et résineux. Saveurs de citron sucré, résineux, légère amertume de houblon.

Bottle at home. Pour is hazy orange juice with a frothy white head and great lacing. Big honeydew and melon, papaya, apricots, mandarins, pineapple, biscuit, and grass in the aroma. Awesome fruitiness. Taste is juicy grapefruit, papaya, delicate fruit rind, more honeydew, biscuit, oranges, and maraschino cherries with a medium bitter. Full body with crisp carbonation. Clean, balanced, fruity, and extremely drinkable. This drinks amazingly smooth with giant fruit characteristics. Nice!

Consumed near the source within 6 hours of hitting the shelves. Pours a beautiful pale orange, with a medium white fluffy head. Nose is full of passionfruit, guava, citrus fruit, dank resiny hops. Flavor is packed with tropical fruits (melon, passionfruit, guava), citrus, piney hops in the backseat. Leaves you with a lightly bitter hop finish, just enough. Mouthfeel is very nice, very sticky / gooey, somewhat juicy. This stuff is the real deal, its a beauty... drink it fresh.

Pours an orangey golden with a thin layer of fine white foam. Most entirely clear from a bottle with sediment at the bottom. Strong and pleasant citrus aromas no type of incompatible caramelization, Maillard flavors. No honey. No biscuit. A touch of pine on the edges with some tropical fruit flavors emerging as it warms. FInishes with a moderate bitterness mostly balanced by some residual sweetness. The feel is slightly crisp with a creamy edge not marred by residual sugar. Overall an outstanding beer, simple and very well expressed.

Pretty amazing DIPA. Earthy, herbal and slightly fruity aroma. Very crisp taste. Good carbonation and beautiful juicy hop flavors. Delicious beer

Sharp pine resin and tropical fruit aroma. Oranges, mangos and peaches. Flavor has a tropical fruit sweetness about it backed by a good biscuit malt base. Its the closest thing Ive to sunshine in a bottle. Outstanding!

Cloudy orange with a finger of white head. Big citrus nose, orange grapefruit, mango, pineapple, pine, slight floral note. Taste is just like the nose. No alcohol detectable. Fantastic DIPA, right in my wheelhouse.

Bomber at a bottle share. Pours a hazy darker gold with a nice white head. Aroma of citrus, tropical, and grass. Taste is grapefruit, pineapple, other tropical fruits, grass, and some malt. Very nice IPA.
Not sure how I havent rated this. Bottles and on draft. Golden pour with white head. Super citrus and light herbal and fresh grassy hop aromas. Flavor follows, delicious and solid double ipa.
Ive had Pliny and Heady in the recent past and this one is not even in the same class as those. Big hop aroma. Too dry of a finish and harsh on the tongue.

Javais beaucoup dattentes en buvant cette fameuse Double Sunshine qui est constamment comparée à la Heady Topper. Elles sont toutes deux brassées au Vermont, mais les similitudes sarrêtent pas mal là. Cest un beau nectar doré et trouble surmonté dune montagne de mousse dessinant une belle dentelle qui remplit le verre. Un nez majoritairement constitué de cultivars dhoublons ouest-américains est saisissant et fait baver. En bouche, un bel équilibre entre les qualités aromatiques et amérisantes est bien maîtrisé, ça se boit incroyablement bien, mais ce nest rien à côté de la Heady ...
a pretty well rounded IPA, not too heavy on the hops or anything else. very nice.

A: Pours a clear golden orange color with a white foamy head on top, nice retention with streaky lacing all down the sides.

S: I was expecting it to be much more pungent but still very nice. I smell alot of tropical fruit (mango, pineapple) to start then some citrus, orange, and grapefruit. There was a little bit of pine and light caramel. A bit of sweetness as well. 

T: Just like the aroma lots of citrus fruit mixed with a little bit of pine. Grapefruit and a big of orange and orange peel. On the back end it get bready malt notes.

M: Medium bodied with moderate carbonation, dry on the tongue (love that). 

O: Really enjoy this beer but not as in your face as I thought it would be, really nice aroma and flavor that is dry and not really sweet. One of my favorites for sure.

65cl, new exclusive American brew Anno 2010, thx alot to Secret Santa for the extra!, complex bitter brew, fruity/bitter and slightly sweet, very balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew

Liquid gold is the color, huge head that settles to 3 fingers, quite billowing. Rings cling to the side of the glass, swirling of bubbles ate every pour. Aroma is strong: clementines, tangerines, sweet peaches in fruit syrup, bit of sweetness, rich fruit. Flavor is a rush of sweet fruit, fleshy orange, less intense than smell. Low carbonation and low lying bitterness. Noticing that Lawson makes balanced IPAs, not hop bombs. Very happy to have tried this.

This one poured a darker yellow with a white head. Aroma was of tropical fruit, lots of oranges and green hops . Flavor was lightly dank, mainly orangey and herbal hops. Lightly tropical too. Good, not great.

On tap at Prohibition Pig: pours hazy golden with a thin white head. Aroma citrus heavy. Flavor is grapefruit, mango and pepper on the back end. Malt balances the hops well. Full flavor, perfectly carbonated this is an awesome beer.

22 oz bottle shared with the group. Pours a hazy dark golden color with a small white head. The aroma and flavor have tropical fruit, citrus, dank and catty hops, a sizable enough malt backbone to stand up to the hops, caramel, toast, with hints of spicy hops as well. Good flavor and easy to drink even with the big hop profile.

After one of the early kegs kicked at Blind Tigers VSK night they threw this gem on causing almost a stampede to the bar. Pours orange golden with fluffy white head. Nose of huge tropical fruit. This is bursting with juicy hop flavors, pineapple, mangoes, grapefruit, some pepper and earthy bitterness. Drying finish with medium body, fresh and delicious and amazing

There's a wonderful aroma. Followed by wonderful taste. Followed by wonderful after-taste. Overall, this beer is wonderful.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2014 Bottle: Thanks, Alex! Bright, radiant gold with a big, slow settling foamy white head that leaves nice lacing behind. Aroma is huge citrus & tropical hops; pungent pineapple, mango, tangerines, papaya, grapefruit. Huge pungency & awesome hop oils... Dripping wet, gushing fruits. Taste is... Amazing. Pungent, juicy hops. Citrus, mango, pineapple, orange, papaya, sticky hop leaves, dank resins... Just a touch of cracker malt, not sweet at all. Perfect bitterness... Nice pine & fruit finish, dry and long lasting. Fantastic, world class. Double Sunshine is the best DIPA Ive ever had.

A: Hazy Orange Hue, Passes Some Light, Great White Head, Great Lacing

S: Grapefruit, Piney, Orange Zest, Mildly Boozy

M: Great Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Bitter, Boozy

Overall, a great beer for the style, well put together but the booziness gets too powerful as it warms up, but still a great beer to experience.
Bottle pour. Im really liking this one. Strong orange flavors with great hop balance! A really strong floral aroma as well. This is an exceptional DIPA.
22oz bottle, from a trade. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Nose is big citrus and hops. Flavor is grass, pineapple, citrus, bread. Bitter finish. Overall very good.

Bottle from most recent Coop release poured into Lawsons snifter 8/23/13. Bottle is 1 week old based on when it was purchased. 

A- Pours a cloudy orange hue with a two inch fluffy white head. Medium to high carbonation is visible. Excellent retention and lacing. Over a few minutes, the head fades down to a quarter inch plug over the beer. 

S- Big dank hops followed by a blast of grapefruit, mango, and a little spicy note as well. Very small caramel malt aroma that is all but covered up by the tropical fruit and piney hop character. 

T- The initial sip before you swallow makes it seem like the beer will be a lot more tame than it really is. An absolute blast of grapefruit and pine intertwined with mango, orange zest, and an intense bitter note that leaves you wanting more of the beginning sip. 

M- The carbonation is medium at best, and overall the body is right in the middle of the road. This beer finishes extremely dry, accentuating the bitter notes and making it go down way too easy. I could drink a pint of this in a few minutes without even realizing where it had gone. There is a slight indication of the alcohol, but it is forgotten by the huge aroma and flavor this beer throws at you. 

O- Not my first time having this gem, and hopefully not my last either. An absolute treat to drink- definitely in my top 5 DIPAS, behind HF S&S 5 and 6, although this is solidly more drinkable than either Heady Topper or Pliny. A hopheads paradise.

Review #850

22 oz bottle served in a Lawsons snifter. Bottle a few days before imbibing. Huge thanks to kevanb for the share.

A: Pours a yellowish orange color with a slight chilled haze to it. One finger of white foam forms on the pour and recedes to a thin cap. Soapy lace is left down the glass.

S: Tons of citrus fruit on the nose. Hefty amounts of grapefruit with a mild tangerine/orange citrus sweetness. Minimal biscuit malt in the background as this is all about the hops.

T: The taste is even better and much balanced. A ton of grapefruit with fruity and earthy tone to it. Pineapple and mango tropical fruits with a sweet biscuit malt body to give it a little tangent amongst the heavy fruit brightness. Light bitterness rounds it out.

M: Light bodied with a medium carbonation level. This drinks like a single IPA/Pale ale with the flavor of a big DIPA. Huge drinkability.

O: Dangerously drinkable with a great representation of grapefruit. Probably the best Ive ever tasted or smelt in a beer. Absolutely delicious and incredibly balanced. Hopefully Ill get to try this again sometime.

text: 17th September 2013Craft Clerkenwell. Tuesday Horal Chugging Tasting! Cheers to Leighton for the best beer of the night. Lightly hazy gold beer with a good white head. Bottle shared at Sanders in NYC. Pours clear gold with a crothy white head. Smells unbelievable. Loads of juicy citrua, mandarin orange, straw, pale malts. On tap in snifter. Poured a clear yellow with nice, average head. Aroma is incredible. Very floral and citrusy in the nose. Light and cities on the tongue with great hop balance. Truly an amazing beer.

Bomber to taster (shared by alexsdad06). Looks good; a hazy golden orange with white head. Smells and tastes great! A wonderful balance of juicy hops with a well-balanced pale malt backbone. nice on the palate. Great stuff! Reminds me of Heady Topper.

Bottle - thanks Jake! Pours hazy butterscotch with a small off-white head that dissipates with nice lacing. Aroma is very citrus, grapefruit, passionfruit, cat piss. Pretty much nails the sweet spot there. Flavor is much the same, light sweet, medium bitter. A bit harsh, but otherwise pretty tasty. Medium body, oily mouthfeel. Definitely a good one.

bottled poured into a pint glass, nice foamy white head. smell of citrus and mango. flavor was very nice, citrusy hops. orange zest and lemon peel, sweet pinapple. very well balanced and delicious DIPA

I poured a 16.375oz bottle into a mug (which, if you look closely, says "Sunshine Fair" on it). There was no freshness date on the bottle, though I got this from a friend (thanks, Jon!) who bought it at the brewery for $9 ($0.55 per ounce).

Appearance: Bright golden/yellow hue - almost glowing with intensity. Fairly hazy, but carbonation still visible. Forms a large, ivory, frothy head which laces and retains quite well.

Smell: Strong tropical fruit notes, especially grapefruit, pineapple and passion fruit. Theres a distinct herbal aroma as well - almost garlicky.

Taste: I recently noted that the "New England Style" IPA seems to be catching on and this is yet another beer exemplifying some of the great brewing thats taking place in the northeast section of America. Much like a West Coast IPA, Lawsons Finest Double Sunshine IPA has a lot of citrus and stone fruit notes, but ends much differently with a distinct herbal and spicy flavor. Its repetitive and simplistic, but its tasty and thats what matters.

The hops are definitely in control of the palette here. They start out with an almost nectar-like sensation of tropical fruit juice concentrate. Its sweet like a glass of breakfast juice, but at the same time still dank and bitter. At the crest of the swig the bitterness increases exponentially, imparting rustic, herbal and spicy flavors. Ground up tree bark plus garlic and herbal tea. Its dry, but not completely arid. Theres additional fruit flavors on the finish, though there isnt a lot of distinct malt character per se. The hops linger, leaving an aftertaste akin to garlic bread. Usually, I really enjoy this combination, but its a little too spicy for me to give it my highest rating. 

Drinkability: Though Lawsons Finest Double Sunshine IPA is packed with flavor, its not a difficult beer to drink. The mouthfeel is intense with taste, but not carbonation. The mouthfeel is fairly soft and it goes down smooth. There is a drying sensation that lingers, but its highly tolerable. I do notice a bit of warmth from the 8% ABV. It works with the bitterness for the most part, and I would not consider it distracting. A fine double IPA to enjoy on its own because of its rarity and price (though if it were readily available and reasonably priced, itd be perfect with a spicy meal).

hazy pale orange pour out of a bomber. froathy white head that lasts throughout the glass and leaves some soapy lacing. bright tropical fruit aroma.. grapefruit, lemon and orange peel. juicy grapefruit and pine flavors stand out with a balanced bitterness. clean aroma and flavors. a very well done dipa!

Double Sunshine pours about medium orange. Darker than I expected. Its quite hazy, and that cloudiness makes the color seem a bit flat, rather than glowy. On the other hand, it has a truly excellent head. The foam is a bit rocky and bone white. Very good retention. A couple inches of bubbles stayed up for a long time, and theres lots of lacing. Bubbles are all over the walls of the glass. 

The aroma is a superb tropic fruit salad of hoppiness. Pineapple and mango for days. Theres also some bright tangerine, lemon and peach flavors in the mix and a touch of pine at the end. Best of all, the aroma is fresh and strong. Hops hit me right as the cap came off the bottle. Juicy as can be. Theres probably a touch of pale malt in the background, but this is a hop party. 

The taste is similarly loaded to the gills with tropical fruit hop flavors, though theres a bit more citrus to it. It tastes like pineapple-tangerine joy. Its sweet and bright, but the hops show a little muscle with some solid bitterness that courses through each sip. However, its among the most flavorful bitter hop notes that Ive come across, just a perfect level to keep the sweetness from running away. Mild honey-ish pale malt flavors hold up all of these wonderful hop flavors, and it stays appropriately out of the way. Finish is long and full of pineapple, pine and grapefruit hop flavors. 

Mouthfeel is creamy and full, but the beer still seems pretty light. Theres a very pleasant hop oiliness to the beer. Carbonation is pretty normal. Good stuff.

This is an absolutely wonderful beer. Ive had a lot of DIPAs, and this one is way up near the top for me. The hop flavors are big, juicy and bright, and the tropical fruitiness is just great. I particularly like the flavor-packed taste, which doesnt scrimp too much on bitterness. The malt doesnt get in the way, and there are simply no real flaws to point out.

22 oz bottle, rating #100!  Surprise gift from my friend in VT.  Lightly hazed orange brown with white frosting.  Nose is caramel, pineapple, mango, spicy pine and black pepper. First sip reminds me of canned fruit salad, but in a good way.  Cardamon and cherry sweetness draw you in; pineapple, mango, peach, grapefruit peel and lingering key lime.  Just below my top 2 DIPAs but still showing the same total sensory immersion that distinguish my favorites.

22 oz. bottle all to myself! Poured into a Lost Abbey teku glass. Pours cloudy bright orange with bright yellow cloudiness. Looks magnificent in the sunlight. Taste is complex, with much of the above stated tropical fruits, and malt sweetness to back it up. Completely well balanced flavors and juicy, creamy mouth fell. Lots of citrus and floral notes on the tongue, some pine and bitter grapefruit on the finish. Beautiful lacing the whole way down. Finish is a touch too juicy with some dryness, and a nice soft alcohol warmth. Aftertaste is like licking a rainbow made of hop varietals. If the finish was a little more dry this would be the perfect DIPA. Incredible.

O: The first few sips reminded me a fair bit of a more mellow Hopslam.  Each successive sip established this as a very good, but not mindblowing dIPA.  Would love to drink again.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2014 3 drafts so far at blind tiger with scarlett and Jeremy. Pours a bright hazy orange with slight white lacing. Aroma is the most freshest citrus, lemon, grapefruit, and bitter orange peel and light lime. Mouthfeel is incredibly smooth and refreshing with notes of citrus, pine, grapefruit, light funk and faint mineral character. Amazing citrus double ipa.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2014 Bottle on many occasion. Poured a hazed out yellow gold color. Small white head that was very thick. Aroma is an explosion of hops, including notes of grapefruit, citra, lemongrass, pine, earthy malts and hops throughout. Taste is a salivating hop bomb of citrus fuels including lime, grapefruit, mango, lemon zest. Flavor was indeed a lingerer. I wanted more of this badly but we only had a bottle to share for the table. Huge thanks to whoever cracked this. Def in my top three of this year next to bitter valentine and heady topper. I have now had this beer enough to know it is indeed one of if not the best imperial ipas in the world. Perfect in all aspects. Lowered it one notch since the last 4 batches(12-13) I have had arent the same as what it used to taste like,

22oz bomber from caguiar.

Pours a hazy golden orange with a small wispy white head that recedes to a swirl of foam and thick collar.

Aroma is massively hoppy with mostly juicy citrus hops - pithy white grapefruit and orange zest.  Some lemongrass and pien resin underneath the citrus.  There is a bit of bready malt sweetness but definitely not a lot of balance in the nose.

The taste has a mix of oranges and pineapple citrus with a hefty floral dankness with some herbal and grassy notes.  The finish is bitter and resinous.

Mouthfeel is medium to full bodiied and well carbonated.  I do get a hint of alcohol burn in the finish which surprised me a little but didnt take away from the beer.

Another outstanding hoppy beer from Lawsons.  I was a big fan of the Triple Play I just tasted and this is even better I think.

Bottle provided by Baron. Beer pours a lemon yellow, with about a half fingers worth of white head. Spectacular nose, its grassy and pine with some sweetness. Flavor is dry and resinous, nice piney flavor, some grass. Solid carbonation, medium mouthfeel, well hidden booze, moderate bitterness. Everybody at our tasting thought this sucked, but they are out of their element. Its one of the best east coast DIPAs available. It has everything Im looking for in a nice west coast DIPA.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2012 Pours out golden with plentiful white head.  Its bitter, grassy, piney and theres a touch of citrus.  Not much malt.  Palate is crisp and wll carbonated.  Tasty, but doesnt quite reach the top tier of DIPAs (for me).  I wish I could like this one more.  Its better than triple play, but doesnt live up to the top alpine or three floyde DIPAs.
Very earthy aromas emanate from a slightly orange golden beer.  The taste is earthy with some nice spice from the aromas.  Lovely balance.  Malts are in the background.  Great DIPA.

Thanks to Hopsbreath

Appearance- Hazy sunshine color with a small white head. 

Smell- Little bit of an ammonia smell. Some pine and little bit of malt. 

Taste - Pine hop flavor. Some floral, citrus, and ammonia.

Mouthfeel- A rare, thin DIPA. That is the way I like them though. 

Overall- This started out rather well. Piney and a little citrus. After it warmed up a bit, however, it kinda gave off a weird, funky taste. Didnt really like it after that. Maybe it was just me though.

Bomber into Kuhnhenn snifter.  Hazy/cloudy gold with a white head that dissapates quickly.  Aroma is of light grapefruit zest, slightly tropical and some muddled hops.  Flavor is mostly bitter grapefruit, mixed citrus zest, mint, pine slight pineapple.  Very bitter with a super dry finish.  Prickly carbonation.  Pretty good, but I was expecting more.

Bottle, thanks to emileer, 03/01/2012.  Pours apricot hue, hazy, 2-finger head with great retention and lively bubbles evident.  Soft, almost floral rich hop aroma of grapefruit, tropical fruit, super dank, resin met by caramel malts, slight bread.  Lots of citrus upfront in the taste, more dank hoppiness with a pine edge, caramel counterbalance washed away with bitter grapefruit finish.  Medium full palate, resinous without being too sticky, alcohol hidden to remain smooth, balanced.  Great Double IPA, cant understate how dank this was, for lack of a better word.  Thicker in character than, say, an Alpine brew, but just as tasty.

(bottle at Daks).  Pours a cloudy yellow with white head.  Aroma has lots of citrusy hops.  Taste is sweet with some light, citrusy bitterness.  Lighter bodied and dry finish.  The beer is very dry and bitter, but still quite good.

Bomber pours somewhat hazy orange yellow with copper hues here and there with thin white head. Kind of un-assuming look to it. The aroma is . . .drool inducing chewy hoppiness from front to back with bold spicy hop notes grudgingly giving up a bit of ground to some earthy dankness and brighter notes of lemon like acidity and tropical fruit notes. Wowzers! Very nice, the taste does not dissapoint after the wonderful snoot full of hoppy aromatics. The taste has the same bold chewy spicy hop notes mixing with citrus like grapefruit and malt sweetened lime juice. This slides hoppy like into the finish leaving hoppy spicy and citrus goodness lingering deep into the after taste. I could serious drink a shit-ton of this! Well done. Big bold and dangeriously drinkable.
UPDATED: MAY 26, 2013 Bouteille. Nez de miel et dÃ¢â¬â¢agrumes. Bouche intense et resineuse sur le pamplemousse rose. Excellente!

On tap at The Farmhouse Tap and Grille Burlington VT.
Pours a hazy golden orange color with a fluffy white head that sticks around for a while. Smells of pine, citrus, apricot, lemons, grapefruit, malt maybe. Taste is slightly bitter with lots of fruity citrusy hop goodness. Smooth resinous mouthfeel with a medium body and a moderate level of carbonation. This didnt look like much in the glass but was really nice going down. Too bad this is so frikin hard to find.

Thanks to deuane for sharing this one with thain709 and myself. I have wanted to try this one for a little while now, thanks for the chance buddy.

A - Pours murky golden orange with a nice one finger tall white head leaving light rings of lace down the glass. I got the last of the bottle so mine was a little murkier than the others.

S - Smells of pungent grapefruits, citric hops, fresh pine needles and a growing caramel sweetness. I would say that the nose is the best part of this beer.

T - Starts off with a nice citric hop punch quickly giving way to hints of pine resin, sweet caramel malt, fresh cut grass and some light citric fruit. The fruit and hops are fading quick but there is still plenty there to carry this one to the finish. Finish is pretty dry, lingering for some time.

M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Smooth, hoppy feel leaving the pallet dry, as it should, long after the finish.

O - I am pretty sure this one was around two weeks old and it was pretty good. The taste was a bit of a letdown from the nose but it was still very easy to drink and it packs lots of flavor. Cant wait for my next run in with this one.

[200th Imperial IPA] 22 oz. bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks Dany!), pours a mostly clear golden with a small white head. Beautiful piney hop aroma explodes on the nose, with some herbal and tropical fruit notes - just enough malt to back. Flavour is loaded with a barrage of piney hops, some orange peel, sort of herbally notes and sufficient pale malt backing, though the piney hops still scream to the surface. Dry palate of piney hops that coat the palate and dominate. Quite an astringent aftertaste. Excellent.

Pour form a bottle courtesy of a recent trade. Slightly hazy golden orange n color. Decent white top.Very fruity aroma of grapefruit,orange, lemon, and peach. Super flavorful hop flavors of tropical goodness initially. Mouthfeel is slick  and full. The bitter pungent hops kick in and perfectly balance the sweet fruity flavors. The finish is dry and bitter and long lasting. Great DIPA and would love more of this one.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2012 Re-Rate: Purchased at Warren Store in Vermont a mere days after it being released. Placed it in the fridge over the weekend so enjoying this abou ta week after it was bottled. Poured at 45 Degrees F into a Stell Artois Glass.

A - Gorgeous pour. SRM of 8.5. Deep orange appearance like a light orange soda. Very rich hazy appearance. My standard pour yielded a 2 finger off white to slight yellow head with a creamy top that subsided very little in 5 minutes.

S - Delicious dry hop aroma. Nice grapefruit and orange zest smells followed by lemon juice, a bit of apricot and pineapple. Theres a mild spice to this beer. 

T - Well, Im going to try my best to get the hop profiles correct. Im getting Centennial, Columbus and Amarillo hops. Dry hop is citra and this leads me to an overwhelming ruby red grapefruit taste. Mild pepper notes and a weak level of orange skins. Reminds me of my whole juiced oranges I have every day at home. Finish is a fleeting dry hop taste and almonds.

M - 60% carbonation on the mouth swish. Heavy body for an IPA. Mouth feel is slick and the dry hops stick around for a nice bit of time.

O - When I first rated this beer in January, it was perhaps my 5th IPA ever and the 2nd IPA I had ever rated. Now, Ive rated about 50 and had over 100 IPAs since then. So, now that my palate has changed a bit, I dont think its as good as it was when I first had it. Its still a "nectar of the gods" sort of beer but its no Heady Topper and it doesnt stand up to the hoppy beers released by Hill Farmstead. Still, Double Sunshine is worth seeking out as it is delicious. Just make sure you get it fresh.

Mmmmm...like licking a pine needles soaked in citrus and mangos. The aroma is very much tropical and citrus and the flavor is some piney goodness. This is my kind of IPA. Not for the weak, My non beer geek friends/family wouldnt touch this so more for me and the wife.

Was absolutely blown away by this...and it wasnt the best bottle of the night!  24 karat pour with a fluffy ivory head that left a bit of lacing.  Aroma is pungent and mind numbing with incredibly bright grapefruit, orange peel, mango, papaya, pineapple, lemon zest, and guava.  The tropical fruit and citrus presence is unbelievable along with hints of ganja.  A bottled version of Lou-P-Lin that holds up incredibly to age.  Cant even imagine this on tap.  Love the this is only 8%...could drink this all day, every day!  World-class!

Bottle from Boltz! Thanks man! Sparkly yellow/gold with a big bubbled white head.  Dank, tropcial fruit, citrus hops all over the place!  Flavor is so juicy and hoppy, tropical fruit, citrus, just freaking delicious!

Bottle shared by Phaleslu. Thanks Peter! Pours golden with a light white head. Aroma is citrus, grapefruit, floral hops and sweet malts. Flavor is nice and fruity with caramel malts. Medium to light bodied with moderate carbonation. Finish is not as bitter as I thought it would be for a DIPA. Pretty good overall.

22 oz. bottle from lushawn- thanks a ton, Shawn! Pours a cloudy peach gold color with a small eggshell white head. Aroma of overripe fruits, pineapple, citrus peel, citrusy and floral hops, and sweet malts. Really nice, fruity flavor: melon, pineapple, peach, sweet and caramel malts, and mango. Medium-bodied, with a sweet, juicy mouthfel and moderate carbonation. Way more fruity than bitter. Easy to drink DIPA.

22oz bottle-shared by hbmason, thanks Tim-pours hazy gold with an offwhite head.  Aroma is citrus zest/floral, some light malt.  Taste is very floral-chysanthimum/citrus hop bit, some light malt.  Dry/crisp.

Date: January 01, 2011
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Dan NYE
Appearance: cloudy gold, fine off white head, streaks of lace
Aroma: big citrus hop aroma
Flavor: sweet malt flavor, lots of citrus hops, balancing bitterness, long bitter finish
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *** /4

Bottle This beer rocks! Clear golden ale with a small, creamy, white head. Good retention. The aroma furnishes fruity, earthy and musky notes of cat piss and grapefruit rind. Full-bodied with a milky mouthfeel and laid-back carbonation. Flavorful and mega bitter  earthy, fruity hops. Finishes bitter, bitter and bitter. For a double Ipa, this stuff is darn nice. World class bottle of beer courtesy of landhoney. Thanks, Seth!
Bottle shared by Seth.  Clear pale yellow pour.  Grapefruity hop aromas.  Super dry with floral and herbal notes.  A little unbalanced.

Bottle from hbmason...thanks Tim! - Pours honey yellow with a thinnish off-white head. Aroma is a huge blast of tropical fruit and that onion/garlic note that Ive smelled before. Lots of herbal hops and a sweet malt backbone. Really bright...wow. Taste is more sharp--lots of really bitter citrus rind that lasts through the long finish. A bit minty with a good deal of syrupy sweet malt. A bit too bitter for my tastes, but it kind of grew on me too. Slick and resiny, with pretty little carbonation.

Bottle from Ethan, shared with Mike.  Hazy gold with a ncie white head.  Nose is citra - sweaty lemon, pineapple, some mint.  That all continues into the flavor - strange sweaty citrus and a slightly funky bitterness.  A bit heavy in terms of mouthfeel.  A bit more bitter than I would prefer.  Still, a solid beer.

bottle, shared with Rudolf, somewhat cloudy golden yellow orange. very citrusy, grapefruit, pineapple, lemon rind. citrusy bitterness, not sharp blunt bitterness, continual citrus driven bitterness, juicy. nice beer

Huge thanks to koopa for sharing this one. 

Pours a cloudy, golden sunshine color with orange and lemon yellow hues and a one finger white head that slowly settles into a lasting ring. Spotty lacing left behind.

Sweet citrus hop aroma with dank, resinous hop oils and tons of citrus and tropical. fruit. Slightly piny with lots of pineapple, grapefruit and lemon peel.

Medium bodied with a blast a dry, earhy hops which provide a perfect dry bitterness that lingers over the sweet fruit notes into a bone dry finish.  Lots of grapefruit and sweet pineapple along with zesty lemon peel.  Pale malt backbone with biscuit and cracker providing a nice counter without taking away from the hop bitterness.  Simply put, this beer tastes amazing.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2012 On tap at three penny taproom.  First offering by Lawsons and was not dissapointed.  What a balanced citrus/dank IPA.  Just the right amount of malty sweetness to compliment the HUGE hop profile.  VT continues to make the most consistently amazing IPAs.
UPDATED: JAN 21, 2012 On tap, big hop flavors, tons if citra. Not very bitter, mango and tropical flavors. Did not except this to rock this much.
On draft.  Yellow color with a nice white head.  Citrus and pineapple in aroma and taste.  Complex and nice.

This pours bright amber orange with a decent head. The aroma gives notes of fresh tangerines, mango, and a bit of booziness. There are flavors of citrusy smooth hops and you get a subtle blend of bitter and sweet flavors, although the bitterness lingers on the tongue a bit longer. The body is medium to light with good carbonation.
22oz bomber.  Fairly light pale ale pour.  Typical fruity nose but a very unpleasent body order type scent dominates.  Taste was fruity and quite good.  I just cant get past the nose.

good floral dipa, more of a west coast style ipa than east coast, very floral and grapefruit more than citrusy, which is nice in a dipa. easy to drink and more than likely, share with a friend, abv is hidden well.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2014 Tap at ACBF. Hazy copper pour with a fluffy head. Aroma and flavor are both slammed with peach, apricot, mango, and pine hop presence. Reminds me a bit of Sculpin, but more sticky and sweet, and with more evergreen. The hops at the finish lose just a touch of its character and become more non-descript in their bitterness, which keeps this from the upper echelon of the style. Still, very good.

Rerate 9/14/14 -- Ive had this a couple times since my first rating, but this is the bottle that made me want to up my rating. Gorgeously clean on the palate, and there is a remarkable combination of sticky, old school resinous hops still in the foreground, but beautiful mango and papaya shows itself in the background as well. Lovely stuff.

Thx to BaconSausage for the surprise!  Batch 204 bottle 30.  Hazy gold pour with a fluffy white head and a little spotty lace.  Tropical fruit aroma with a twist of pine.  Flavor follows suite maybe a little too much malt if I had to nit pick but otherwise a solid brew.
bottle shared by kan! Pours gold with white head. nose has bright grapefruit juice, grass piney resin, flavors have good hoppage of tropicals, mango, clementines, very good stuff

22 oz bottle shared at Kans. Thanks! Pours a nice well hazed golden hue, a bit darker but glowing with moderate frothy head. Laces ok. Aromas are vibrant citrus, melons and grapefruit with some bready malts, toast, and pale malts. With some rounded citrus, florals. Initial is medium bodied, a healthy citrus bite, lemons and grapefrui, oranges moving into peaches, vibrant florals, touches of grass, some light dry pine. Finish is dry, some sticky malts, bready, with some toast. Lingering sticky sweet malts, bright vibrant citrus and florals. Mmmmmm. A bit sweet into the finish but light and easily drinkable.

Huge, huge thanks to imagineiii for sending this bottle my way. Ive been looking to try this for awhile now. Served in a Bruery tulip.

Pours a bright, clear golden yellow color with a good white head and plenty of lacing as it goes down. The nose immediately lets me know that this is going to be delicious. It has loads of citrus character along with a bit of pine; slightly dank. Great hoppiness. The flavor carries the same notes, and the citrus hop character pairs really well with a great amount of bitterness. Very good. Light to medium body with a great dry finish. Very, very nice overall.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-21-2011

So glad to get a taste of this - thanks, main man! I found it a very nice DIPA, with a mix of extremely pungent dry hops and quite assertive fruit, specifically pineapple. Lovely mouthfeel, creamy and crisp at once. Yummy as it is, seems to get a bit more raves than normal owing to its rarity. But still a rocker.

Props to Chris for this super fresh bottle, batch 192, bottle # 117... Pours a murky light gold, dark in the middle, a little ugly. A nice white head, great retention and lacing... The aroma is fantastic, so fresh, just plucked pine needles with pineapples and an assortment of tropical fruits... Taste is equally great, bitting pine and alcohol of a dipa, but muted and so drinkable. This is awesome, must try.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 In short: A superb easy to drink blonde Double IPA with a complex hop profile.
How: Tap at Black Back pub, Waterbury VT
The look: Cloudy blonde body topped by a medium white head with good retention
In long: Nose is an explosion of floral, tropical fruits, grassy and foresty hops.  Its all there, its bright and vibrant.  Plenty of crackers-like pale malts to provide a full body while leaving all the flavor space to for the hops.  Aforementioned hops (floral, tropical fruits, grassy and foresty) in large quantities.  Despite being a heavily hopped 8% brew the beer is actually not aggressive.  No alcohol presence.  Somewhat refreshing and sessinonable (ouch!).  Another mighty fine hoppy ale from Lawsons.  I hope Lawsons will one day expand their operation because they make superb IPAs.  Man that was good.  I had too much to drink again at this beer event and now Im afraid there might actually be something wrong with me.  Its probably nothing but sometimes I wonder if I should I be concerned that my liver is making strange noises or that my right testicle is larger than my other two.

Bottle, Draft, Bottle, and Bottle.  How f lucky ive been this year.  This IPA kicks serious ass.  Pours a golden orange body with a white head and great head retention.  Really tropical fruit tones, but still with a modest drying finish.  Very fresh cherry, citrus, and punch notes.  Light weed y body with grass and a just dead drying with no residual sweetness that lightens the body.  Great shit.

Bottle shared at the 5,000 party. Poured a slightly chill hazed golden body with a slightly foamy bright white head. Dank aroma of cat piss, spruce and grapefruit. Flavor is nice and bitter with notes of cat litter, grapefruit rind, pine sap. Medium to fuller bodied with strong carbonation. This was an awesome DIPA and for those who are shrugging their shoulders when they read things like "cat piss", "dank" and "pine sap" are not true hop heads!!!

Bottle at the double 5k tasting courtesy of Victor (and then someone else had one later... maybe Derek?), which is good since the keg at Blind Tiger kicked right before I ordered one that night. Pours a hazed gold with a thin white head.  Big dank citrus, sweet candy on the nose.  Smooth and creamy, big citrus notes.  Big juicy earth and citrus.  Long grapefruit finish.  Awesome stuff.

Tap at Blind Tiger during a Vermont beer tasting event; this was the one beer of which I got seconds. Pours a hazy golden-orange with slightly rocky white head. Aroma has a great blend of hibiscus, orange, and grass. The flavor is a balanced mix of many classic IPA notes: juicy citrus, perfume, pine, and hibiscus. Good punch of hops that gently fades. Well done!

Bottle shared at Paul and Ryans 5,000th rate tasting. Pours gold with a thin white head. Big big fresh as hell hoppy aroma, citrus fruits, floral notes, and resinous pine. The flavor has a great balance of bitter an sweet notes, with fruity citric notes, and resinous pine. Outrageously fresh and outrageously delicious.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2016 Bottle I shared at Ryan and Pauls 5000th celebration. Poured a near clear gold with an orange hue and a white head that dissipated slowly to the edges. Aroma was full of pine, slightly dank, with a hint of grapefruit and tropical fruits and a bit of a grain backbone. Flavor had more grapefruit and tropical fruits as well as a strong pine note. Really nicely balanced.
Bottle at Paul and Ryans tasting. Pours clear golden amber. Nose and taste of peach skin, dry citrus, hops, caramel malt, herbal pines and pineapple.

Bottle/22oz - Pours a darkish amber in color with a medium white head that settled to a nice covering over the beer.  Nice.  Some decent lacing on the glass.  Aroma/smell is of both citrus and pine hops. Nice.  Flavor is also is juicy citrus and pine.  Some fruity esters... mango, peach perhaps.  Nice.  Finish is lingering is bitterness from the hops and quite fruity from the esters.  Nice.  Another great beer from a great brewer!

tap at Blind Tiger and again in bottles at Ryan & Pauls 5000 tasting - Arouma is bright floral hops, super fresh. huge resinous bitter hops. Caramel malts but not too sweet like most DIPAs. Finishes dry with some astringency.
Super dope, dank funky hop nose. Shit is super fresh. Taste is lightly sweet, lightly bitter, lots of citrus hops, some honey. Very solid, unfortunately the taste didnt live up to the aroma.

Tap at BT.  Pours a slight hazed golden yellow with a tinge of orange color- nice fluffy tacky white head- some good lace.  Aroma is big powerful fresh citrus hops, light pine and some dankness, mostly orange and some grapefruit- some tropical sweet fruitiness from the hops as well.  Flavor is not sweet at all, just some big juicy hops, orange, mango, then pine zestiness, with a good hoppy bitter finish.  Way too easy to drink.  I think this would have held up well next to all the DIPAs at the Bistro fest last week.  Awesome stuff.

Verre de dégustation, provenant dun fût, dégusté au Winter Beer Gathering 2011 chez Hill Farmstead Brewery (Greensboro, VT). Arôme: Très forte odeur dhoublons floraux et résineux. Apparence: La couleur est orange voilée avec une très faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dhoublons  avec une pointe de fruits tropicauxé. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût houblonné. (Rating #3522)

On tap at Hill Farmstead Winter Gathering 2010..
Appearance : Hazy yellow.

Aroma : Awesome fresh hops. Very sharp and dry. Leafy and fruity hops. Nice notes of passion fruits. Nice malt too.

Taste : Floral and fresh hops. Nice malt with notes of honey. Herbal, floral and a bit resinous. 

Overall : Very nice DIPA. Quite drinkable. Very nice hops. Awesome nose.

Holy smokes.   Super potent big juicy grapefruit. A bit resiny.  Super juicy,  hop forward.  Touch of tangerine sweetness.   Dry.  Touch of alcohol, but not boozy by any means.   Awesome awesome iipa.   Big beautiful juicy hops.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2011 Bottle during the Superbowl; I apologize for the brief notes. This is a fantastic IPA, bursting with fresh, juicy hops. Very tropical rather than citric, with great balancing bitterness. Perfectly dry. Acquire at any cost. Wish I had a case of this to drink for myself.

My Bottom Line:
Coniferous, grassy hop fireworks explode everywhere from aroma to finish for pure, unadulterated Double IPA glory.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A creamy sheet of foam tops the hazy blond.
-The grassy, herbal hop bitterness is intense; this is for hopheads only.
-The fluffy carbonation and svelte body make this quite friendly, offsetting some of the boastful hoppiness.
-Malts are only there to provide a trampoline on which the multifarious hop personality (piney, herbal, citrusy, etc.) can loudly play.
-Alcohol is not a bother in the flavor profile, as it is smothered in hops!

On tap at Hill Farmstead.

Pours a light hazy orange with a medium off white head that laced.  Aroma of tropical fruits, citruss notes, herbal and light caramel malt with other solid malty notes.  But malt def takes a back seat.  Flavor of a nice malt that balanced a great hop selection.  Moderate bitterness.  Citrsu and piney.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2010 22oz bottle (Rare Batch #167, bottle #31) acquired via a recent trade.... pours a hazy, mostly non-transparent, copper orange brown with a pillowy soft frothy white head. kind of looks like a hefe only a bit more orange... bright/pungent/aromatic tropical fruits in the nose, with a little mineral and bubblegum notes take form and provides a nice starting point. some dankness in the background wafts back and forth between the dominating pulls from the assertive nature of the fruit...flavors are bright and juicy, just like the description attests, and backed up adequately with a malt backbone thats present but still allowing the hops to shine.  the hops themselves are tropical fruit in nature with some nice added juicy citrus notes.  finish lends itself to a mild bitterness that has a tendency to linger on the palate.  body is medium to full with adequate carbonation....reading some of the other reviews of Lawsons brews, i was able to ascertain their hoppy brews were first class and this definitetely supports that notion.  with hill farmstead and lawsons creating such fine elixirs, vermont is def becoming a haven for some fantastic, attention-getting, and most of all credible brewing.  now who wants to send me more?  def looking forward to the their hop-zilla which will be consumed very soon.
